nodes.bodyText: Instead of giving a hard-coded timeout value, do you think we could use a CountDownLatch for this so the test doesn't depend on timing?

I don't think so. Maybe I can make it a longer timeout. But if the logic is not working as expected, then the thread will never finish. So I'm not sure how the CountDownLatch can help here. Maybe you can elaborate on your idea?
Not added in this PR. This is auto re-ordering when I apply the latest format.
Why this require an active zkclient? CallbackHandler are in memory object, is there anything we need to connection to ZK?

we subscribe, and the subscription requires ZK connection.
Some of our Helix callback handler implementations will read ZK even for finalizing.
There is no way to prevent any customer-defined handler logic to access ZK for finalizing.

It is complicated to create a listener for subscription. Shall we use some simple way to see whether the connection is alive? For example, just have an exist call for the cluster since it is in HelixManager?

just have an exist call for the cluster since it is in HelixManager? This is already done.
However, this won't prevent if the connection breaks during the cleanup process.
For example, we have 10 callback handlers to reset, the connection breaks at the 5th one. Then the check before this cleanup process won't work. To achieve the goal, an alternative way is keeping checking the connection state in a loop. But that is a bad design compare to using the listener.
Will the call be hanging here as well? If there is no connection, cleanupThread got interrupted, but no one set this value to be true.
We are not waiting for it. It will just return whatever inside. This is a non-blocking call.
The result might be false if the clean up was not done completely due to disconnection.
